commands.title: Global Warming: A Call to Action
commands.subtitle: Understanding the Crisis and Shaping a Sustainable Future

slides.title: Our Warming Planet
slides.content: Global warming refers to the long-term heating of Earth's climate system observed since the pre-industrial period (between 1850 and 1900) due to human activities, primarily fossil fuel burning, which increases heat-trapping greenhouse gas levels in Earth's atmosphere.

elements.description: Stylized globe with rising temperature colors (red, orange, yellow) overlaid on a blue background.  Use a watercolor effect for the globe.
Morph transition to the next slide.

slides.title: The Greenhouse Effect
slides.content: The greenhouse effect is a natural process that warms the Earth's surface. When the Sun's energy reaches the Earth's atmosphere, some of it is reflected back into space and the rest is absorbed and re-radiated by greenhouse gases.  Increased greenhouse gas concentrations trap more heat.

elements.description: Diagram illustrating solar radiation entering the atmosphere, some reflected, some absorbed and re-radiated by greenhouse gases. Use cartoon-style drawings of the sun, earth, and greenhouse gases.
Fade transition.

slides.title: Key Greenhouse Gases
slides.content: The primary greenhouse gases in Earth's atmosphere are water vapor (H2O), carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), and fluorinated gases (e.g., hydrofluorocarbons). Human activities are the main contributors to increased concentrations.

elements.description: Infographic showing the sources of each greenhouse gas (e.g., CO2 from burning fossil fuels, CH4 from agriculture). Use icons representing each source.
Push transition (from right).

slides.title: Evidence of Global Warming
slides.content: Rising global temperatures, melting glaciers and ice sheets, rising sea levels, changes in precipitation patterns, and more frequent extreme weather events are all evidence of global warming.

elements.description: Before-and-after images of melting glaciers.  Use a split-screen effect.
Wipe transition.

slides.title: Impacts on Ecosystems
slides.content: Global warming poses significant threats to ecosystems, leading to habitat loss, species extinction, changes in species distribution, and disruptions in food chains.

elements.description: Collage of images showing the impact on various ecosystems (coral reefs, forests, polar regions). Use a faded, distressed filter on the images to represent degradation.
Reveal transition.

slides.title: Impacts on Human Society
slides.content: Global warming affects human societies through increased heatwaves, droughts, floods, sea-level rise, food shortages, and displacement of populations.

elements.description: Series of icons representing the impacts on human society (e.g., a house underwater for sea-level rise, a cracked earth for drought).  Arrange the icons in a circle.
Zoom transition.

slides.title: Mitigation Strategies
slides.content: Mitigation involves reducing greenhouse gas emissions through measures such as transitioning to renewable energy sources, improving energy efficiency, and promoting sustainable transportation.

elements.description: Images of renewable energy sources (solar panels, wind turbines) and sustainable transportation (electric cars, bicycles).  Use a bright, optimistic color palette.
Fly Through transition.

slides.title: Adaptation Strategies
slides.content: Adaptation involves adjusting to the effects of global warming through measures such as building seawalls, developing drought-resistant crops, and improving disaster preparedness.

elements.description: Illustrations of adaptation strategies (e.g., seawalls, drought-resistant crops). Use a blueprint-style design.
Rotate transition.

slides.title: International Agreements
slides.content: International agreements like the Paris Agreement aim to limit global warming to well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5 degrees Celsius.

elements.description: World map highlighting countries that have ratified the Paris Agreement. Use different shades of green to represent varying levels of commitment.
Fall Over transition.

slides.title: A Sustainable Future
slides.content: By taking action now, we can create a sustainable future for ourselves and future generations.  This requires global cooperation, individual responsibility, and a commitment to innovation.

elements.description: Image of people working together to plant trees or build a sustainable community. Use a bright, optimistic color palette with a focus on green and blue.
Morph transition back to the first slide (modified to show a thriving, healthy planet).
